Assessment 
   
Project Description  Government  agencies’  responsibilities  for  the  management  of 
natural resources have been clarified in recent years, including 
recent reorganization of the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry 
(MAF)  and  establishment  of  the  Water  Resources  and 
Environment  Administration  (WREA).  However,  the  capacity  to 
apply  sound  management  principles  and  practices  are  still 
deficient,  particularly  in  view  of  increasing  devolution  of 
management responsibilities to the provinces. 
 
The  Project  will  address  institutional  and  capacity  building 
requirements  (including  governance  improvements)  to  enable 
improved management of the sector on a sustainable basis while 
contributing to the Government’s overall objectives of enhancing 
agricultural  productivity,  promoting  commercialization  of 
agriculture, and protecting the country’s natural resources. Project 
outputs  comprise  (i)  capacity  built  in  sector  management, 
(ii) investment  in  resource  management  and  productivity 
enhancement, and (iii) an effective project management structure. 
 
Rationale  The  Lao  PDR  has  abundant  natural  resources  and  a  small 
population, of which over 80% is dependent on agriculture for their 
livelihood. Significant numbers of indigenous peoples from a wide 
range of linguistic groups live in upland areas to the north and in 
the southern part of the Lao PDR along the border with Viet Nam. 
They  forge  their  predominantly  subsistence  livelihoods  from 
rotational cropping, which incorporates a heavy dependence on 
the natural forest and water resources. The incidence of poverty in 
these areas is over 60%, and is highest among ethnic groups. 
 
  The institutional and legal framework for sustainable and equitable 
management of agriculture and natural resources (ANR) is weak. 
This is evident in the ambiguity of policies and legislation, as well 
as  inadequate  professional  and  technically  trained  staff  and

ii   
facilities. At the provincial and district levels where most ANR 
management decisions are taken, there is a deficit of expertise 
and  facilities.  The  situation  is  exacerbated  by  budgetary 
constraints  (generally  sufficient  to  meet  staff  salaries,  but 
insufficient for operational and development activities). 
 
The capacity of the ANR sector to support traditional livelihoods is 
coming under unprecedented pressure from the recent influx of 
foreign direct investment (FDI) and consequent granting of land 
concessions. Allowing large-scale commercial development where 
there is a weak regulatory and enforcement framework—without 
adequate analysis of land capability and economic impact, and 
encouraged  by  land  speculation—is  increasingly  resulting  in 
adverse  social  and  environmental  impacts  on  local  people’s 
livelihoods.  It  also  compromises  the  Government’s  ability  to 
preserve  the  country’s  rich  and  diverse  forest  environs 
(deforestation  is  actually  increasing).  Adverse  impacts  on 
ecological  function  and  integrity  include  reduced  recharge  of 
aquifers and storage capacity of reservoirs and reduction in dry 
season  irrigation  areas  (directly  contributing  to  reduced 
agricultural production). Furthermore, the loss of forest, coupled 
with the expansion of economic activities, is likely to result in a 
positive net emission of greenhouse gases with global impact. 
 
While trying to protect the natural resource base, the Government 
is  conscious  of  the  need  to  maximize  productivity  on  existing 
arable land—an area limited by topography, undeveloped water 
resources, and limited market access. Agricultural productivity is 
low  by  the  standards  of  the  Association  of  Southeast  Asian 
Nations (ASEAN), and the recent achievement of broad national 
self-sufficiency in rice can only be maintained if the Government 
continues  to  improve  agricultural  productivity.  Food  insecurity 
remains common, especially in areas where the road network is 
underdeveloped. 
 
Support for proven interventions within an existing implementation 
framework,  which  will  contribute  to  the  Government’s  overall 
sector development objectives and provide practical examples for 
the  enhanced  capacity  of  agency  staff  to  manage  the 
development process, is therefore justified. 
   
Impact and Outcome  The project impact will be more efficient and sustainable natural 
resource  management  and  improved  sector  productivity.  The 
expected outcome will be an enhanced institutional capacity at 
national  and  provincial  levels  to  manage  natural  resource 
utilization in a sustainable manner, resulting in poverty reduction 
and  enhanced  market  linkages.  This  will  be  facilitated  by 
developing a land capability database that describes land use and 
suitability, making information regarding concession awards more 
widely  available,  and  addressing  the  policy  for  protection  of 
traditional  user  rights  (including  food  security).  Successful

iii
development initiatives from earlier projects will be consolidated in 
the form of subprojects. National and provincial staff will apply 
their newly acquired skills by implementing subprojects to make 
investments more sustainable. 
 
The implementation of subprojects will have a direct impact on 
agricultural  productivity,  as  well  as  improving  access  to  (and 
integration with) regional markets and overall protection of the Lao 
PDR biodiversity and environment. Subprojects’ selection criteria 
and design features will encourage poverty targeting, gender and 
ethnic  groups’  participation,  and  linkage  with  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) climate change and Greater Mekong 
Subregion  initiatives.  All  these  impacts  will  contribute  to 
addressing  the  persistent  threats  from  food  deficits  and  rural 
poverty. 
   
Project Investment Plan   The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $36.775 million, 
including taxes and duties of $1.023 million. 
   
Financing Plan  It  is  proposed  that  ADB  provide  a  grant  not  exceeding  the 
equivalent of $20.0 million from its Special Funds resources to 
finance 54.4% of the total project cost. The International Fund for 
Agricultural  Development  (IFAD)  will  provide  a  grant  of  $15.0 
million to finance 40.8% of the total project cost. The Government 
will  contribute  $1.775  million,  accounting  for  4.8%  of  the  total 
project cost, to finance incremental staff salaries and taxes and 
duties.

Implementation  A national project steering committee will be chaired by the vice 
Arrangements  minister of MAF, with representation from the Ministry of Finance; 
MAF’s Department of Planning (DOP), National Agricultural and

iv   
Forestry Extension Services and National Agriculture and Forestry 
Research Institute; National Land Management Authority; Water 
Resources and Environmental Administration; Ministry of Planning 
and Investment; and representatives from Attapeu, Champassak 
Salavane, Savannakhet, and Sekong. This will ensure interagency 
coordination  and  provide  direction  to  the  project  coordination 
office  (PCO).  At  the  provincial  level,  provincial  coordination 
committees  with  equivalent  representation  (including  district 
governors)  will  perform  similar  functions,  chaired  by  the  vice 
governor of the province. 
 
A PCO will be established within MAF’s Department of Planning to 
attend to day-to-day management of the Project. In the provinces, 
it will be supported by a provincial project office (PPO) to be 
established in one of the existing line agencies to achieve the 
necessary coordination of the contributing line agencies. 
 
The PPO staff will work with district and kumban (village cluster) 
staff to support their identification and prioritization of proposed 
subproject  investments,  based  on  selection  criteria  specified. 
Proposals  can  be  initiated  by  government  agencies, 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), or other entities working in 
rural development in the provinces. Proposals will be screened 
and prioritized by the provinces, then submitted to the national 
level  for  approval  after  ratification  by  a  technical  review 
committee. Implementation of subprojects will be the responsibility 
of the proposing entity, which will be contracted to the PCO and 
supervised by the PPO. 
   
Procurement  Goods and services to be financed from the proceeds of the ADB 
grant  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). 
   
Consulting Services  Consulting services will be required at the national level to ensure 
effective implementation and at the provincial level to assume 
responsibility for identification of potential subprojects and their 
implementation.  Staff  will  also  be  needed  for  training  in 
safeguards,  appraisal  techniques,  and  geographic  information 
systems/information management. The Project will finance a total 
of 722 person-months of consulting services (84 person-months 
international  and  638  person-months  national).  The  level  of 
consulting  services  identified  under  the  Project  is  considered 
critical in view of the crucial gaps in capacity in the areas of 
appropriate  technology,  natural  resource  management, 
community  mobilization,  and  subproject  focus  and 
implementation. In addition, national consultants will be recruited 
to assist in feasibility studies and detailed design (including initial 
environmental  assessments,  resettlement  plan  preparation  and 
other safeguard requirements). The consultants will be selected 
and engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time).

Project Benefits and  Capacity  building  activities  will  lead  to  improved  national  and 
Beneficiaries  provincial  capabilities  to  make  informed  decisions  about 
investment  in  the  sector  (public,  private,  and  foreign  direct 
investment);  and  will  enable  maximum  financial  and  economic 
benefits to be derived from this external source of development 
capital. As the scale of land concessions is large in relation to 
existing crop areas and will only increase during the life of the 
Project, project benefits can be expected to be large in scale, 
geographically dispersed, and affect all the rural population. 
 
Benefits from the subproject investments will include increased 
agricultural productivity from irrigation and support of technical 
extension services. Increased commercialization will result from 
rural road rehabilitation and strengthening the linkages between 
producers and domestic/subregional markets. Economically viable 
subprojects  will  contribute  to  local  and  national  food  security, 
address  issues  of  climate  change,  and  promote  regional 
integration. Overall, the integrity of the natural resource base will 
be maintained and the process of managing competing interests 
in their use will be rationalized. 
 
The number of beneficiaries will be substantial, as concession 
land areas affected comprise about half the total cropped area of 
the provinces. The geographical dispersion of the subprojects and 
targeting of investments in border areas mean that beneficiaries 
will include the ethnic groups residing in upland areas. Women will 
also be targeted beneficiaries. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The main institutional risk to the Project lies in potential conflict 
between  relatively  autonomous  provinces  (that  have  enjoyed 
considerable latitude in the award of land concessions) and state 
agencies trying to standardize and rationalize the issuance of land 
concessions (and prevent illegal issuance). This risk has been 
mitigated  by  involving  high-level  political  authority  from  the 
provinces in the project design process, and obtaining widespread 
commitment to reforming the land concessions’ award system. 
Greater  clarity  in  land  allocation  processes  and  increased 
publication of land concessions awards reduce the governance 
risks associated with large-scale land allocations. 
 
A second risk concerns the allocation of funds for operation and 
maintenance (O&M) of rural infrastructure rehabilitated under the 
Project. This is a systemic and ongoing issue, as cash-limited 
provincial  authorities  are  responsible  for  maintenance  of  state 
assets but receive few resources from the national budget to carry 
out  routine  and  periodic  maintenance.  This  issue  has  been 
mitigated  by  (i)  requiring  provinces  in  which  subprojects  are 
located  to  sign  formal  commitments  to  meet  O&M  expenses, 
(ii) the  Government  providing  a  specific  assurance  that  it  will

vi   
allocate sufficient funds for the same purpose, and (iii) ensuring 
that subproject evaluations include norm-based estimates of O&M 
expenses for different types of rural infrastructure.  
 
In addition to governance and sustainability issues, other risks 
include the following: (i) capacity development and training are 
insufficient  to  improve  capacity,  resulting  in  weak  subproject 
design; and (ii) staff leave the Project or the ministry after capacity 
development.  These  will  be  mitigated  by  providing  adequate 
technical  support  and  by  supporting  performance-based 
incentives.  Measures  will  also  be  taken  to  ensure 
institutionalization  of  development  planning  and  administration 
through appropriate skills and partnerships. 
   
Technical Assistance  Technical asisstance (TA) is required in view of the complexity of 
introducing social and environmental safeguards into the process 
for screening and approving investments in the sector. TA is also 
needed because of the limited experience of provincial agencies 
to manage sector development as implementing agencies of an 
international  development  grant,  and  the  limited  technical 
expertise  amongst  government  staff  to  ensure  that 
social/environmental  safeguards  and  other  social/gender  and 
development aspects are incorporated into sector management at 
all  levels  of  government.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  a 
period of 24 months from April 2009 to March 2011. A total of 
42 person-months  of  consulting  services  (18  person-months 
international and 24 person-months national) will be required. All 
consultants will be engaged directly by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  A  Japan  Special  Fund 
grant in the amount of $0.7 million is proposed to ensure such 
support is provided.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on (i) a proposed 
Asian Development Fund grant to the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) for the 
Sustainable Natural Resource Management and Productivity Enhancement Project, and (ii) the 
proposed administration by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) of a grant to be provided by the 
International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). The report also describes the proposed 
technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Sustainable  Natural  Resource  Management  and  Productivity 
Enhancement and if the Board approves the proposed grant and administration of the grant, I, 
acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  The Lao PDR is a sparsely populated, mostly mountainous country, with limited arable 
land (estimated at about 10% of its total area). The population depends primarily on agriculture 
(estimated 80% of the labor force), contributing 42% of the gross domestic product, with rice 
farming alone accounting for 39% of the agricultural gross domestic product.1 Sector growth 
rates were maintained at about 5% per year from 1996 to 2000, but slowed to about 3% per 
year thereafter as restrictions on logging were introduced. Rice accounts for about 80% of the 
cultivated area—comprising about 68,000 hectares (ha) of irrigated production, 620,000 ha of 
rain-fed paddies, and 108,000 ha of upland rice; collectively, these account for the bulk of 
domestic food production. 2 
 
3.  At the household level, food security is mainly women’s responsibility. Livestock is a 
significant contributor to sector output as well as household incomes and nutrition. Growth in 
agricultural production has been impressive since the mid-1990s, partly stimulated by reforms 
supported by ADB through two program loans and by a rapid expansion of the irrigated area3. 
From 1995 to 2005, rice production increased from 1.4 million tons to 2.4 million tons, enabling 
the country to achieve broad national self-sufficiency in 2000. From 1992 to 2003, the incidence 
of poverty declined from 46% to 33%.4 Agriculture is central to both individual livelihoods and 
provincial economies in the proposed project area—covering 40 districts that constitute the 
provinces of Attapeu, Champassak, Salavane, Savannakhet, and Sekong, and located in the 
south of the country.5 Of the total population of 1.96 million, rural poverty is high in half the 
districts.6 Within the “poor” districts, 60% of the villages are considered poor (Supplementary 
Appendix A). The incidence of poverty is highest among upland ethnic groups. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
4.  The agriculture and natural resources (ANR) sector is characterized by low levels of 
productivity, poor agricultural and marketing skills, limited market access, low use of water

resources, limited access to technology, and little access to domestic capital for investment 
(Appendix  2). Weak  governance  and  deficiencies  in  the  state’s  ability  to  achieve  planned 
objectives are notable. The institutional framework for sustainable and equitable management of 
ANR is weak, manifest in ambiguous policies and legislation, and inadequate strengths in 
professional and technically trained staff and facilities. At the provincial and district levels, where 
most of the ANR management decisions are taken, there is a deficit of expertise and facilities. 
The situation is exacerbated because of budgetary constraints (sufficient to meet staff salaries 
but insufficient for operational and development activities). There is only limited formal credit for 
ANR, forcing most farmers to depend on more expensive informal credit. While a few farmer 
organizations exist, farmer and water users associations are generally new, institutionally weak, 
unrepresentative of the poorest and of women, and generally inexperienced to undertake the 
functions they are intended to perform. Overall, the development opportunity is to address 
institutional  weakness  in  natural  resources  management  and  (simultaneously)  to  invest  in 
increasing sector productivity. 
 
5.  The most obvious manifestation of this institutional weakness is in relation to natural 
resources management—especially  land-use  management.  In  the  past  4–5  years,  growing 
demand from neighboring countries for agricultural commodities has attracted investors to the 
Lao PDR either through contract farming to source agricultural commodities for processing, or 
through externally financed direct investment in plantations (e.g., concessions for rubber, sugar, 
cassava, and trees for pulp) usually with foreign expertise. The country has seen a major 
increase in foreign direct investment, which has resulted in unprecedented demand for large 
areas of agricultural and forest land. Concessions were being granted on long leases at very 
low annual rentals ($5–$10 per ha per year for 50 years was not uncommon), with no proper 
financial or economic appraisal and no social and environmental safeguards in place. In an 
attempt to contain this situation, the Government imposed a 1-year moratorium in May 2007 on 
the  granting  of  concessions  in  excess  of  100  ha  by  provinces.  However,  the  lack  of 
transparency of land transactions and inconsistencies in practice across provinces and between 
agencies has continued (despite the establishment of the National Land Management Authority 
under  the  Prime  Minister’s  Office).  Overall,  the  land  issue  has  exposed  confusion  in 
administrative and technical processes, and conflicts between the interests of the state in 
ensuring sustainable patterns of land use to maximize growth and ensure its sustainability, and 
(relatively autonomous) provincial administrations. While FDI should have positive impacts—in 
terms of capital, technology, and skills flows—it is likely that many such investments will be 
environmentally  damaging  (through  short-term  exploitation  or  longer-term  neglect),  non-
transparent (mainly benefiting foreign and non-poor domestic interests and excluding women 
and ethnic groups), and economically sub-optimal (in terms of adding to domestic employment 
and incomes). 
 
6.  The security of smallholder tenure to and use of land and forest resources has an impact 
on the type and variety of crops that households are willing to plant. Consequently, it affects the 
poverty status of communities and social equity (including gender and ethnic dimensions). 
There is a need to define more clearly and formalize rights of land access and use. While most 
of the forest area is classified as production forest, conservation forests (or national biodiversity 
conservation areas) and protection forests are delineated on maps, but actual demarcation has 
yet to take place on the ground. This lack of physical demarcation compromises protection 
policy  and  makes  these  areas  vulnerable  to  encroachment,  leading  to  deforestation  and 
denudation. Over the past few decades, deforestation has been severe because of illegal 
logging, shifting cultivation, and encroachment. This destruction not only represents the loss of 
potentially productive assets, but also results in increased emission of substantial quantities of 
carbon dioxide.

3
 
7.  The other systemic ANR sector problem is low productivity. Factor productivity in the Lao 
PDR is low by the standards of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), and the 
recent achievement of broad national self-sufficiency in rice can only be maintained if gains in 
agricultural productivity can be ensured. Poverty is highest in the more rugged upland areas 
where traditional shifting cultivation provides subsistence existence, complemented with the 
extraction  of  non-timber  forest  products.  There  is  a  need  to  address  food  insecurity  and 
malnutrition, especially where the road network is underdeveloped. A move to more sustainable 
forms of agriculture in the upland environment (away from rice-based “slash and burn” systems) 
needs to be complemented through potential development initiatives that can contribute to 
improving the incomes of communities and households (mainly populated by ethnic groups). In 
addition, enhanced focus on improving productivity in the lowland environment (where the larger 
number of poor households is found) needs to ensure sustainable use of natural resources. In 
the lowlands, there is also a fundamental need to promote ANR sector transition. This would 
(i) encourage  diversification  (into  new  crops  and  products,  e.g.,  niche  products,  livestock, 
coffee); (ii) promote value addition (through improved on- and off-farm processing, better post-
harvest technology, etc.); and (iii) support intensification (e.g., through new crop varieties) to 
raise yields. The challenge exists to integrate more remote and hitherto neglected communities 
into the market economy with more commercial yet sustainable agricultural production systems. 
 
1.  Lessons 
8.  In 2005, a sector assistance program evaluation concluded that the contribution of ADB-
financed  investment  projects  to  the  performance  of  the  ANR  sector  had  been  limited.  It 
recommended that ADB activities in the ANR sector should be more selective and focused in 
terms of composition and spread, and should take into account government priorities, the 
division of roles and responsibilities among development partners, past performance of ADB 
operations, identified lessons, and ADB’s comparative advantage and skills mix requirements. It 
also recommended that the future approach should include using existing aid coordination 
channels more effectively to (i) share experience and knowledge, (ii) find solutions to binding 
constraints facing the ANR sector, and (iii) develop replicable approaches that can provide

4.  Project Rationale 
13.  As FDI is likely to be the main source of investment in the sector in the immediate future 
(domestic capital formation is low, and ANR sector enterprises are predominantly small and 
medium-sized enterprises), the Government has an interest in managing FDI to ensure that 
potentially beneficial aspects are realized and that harmful elements are avoided. In pursuit of 
food security and developing smallholders’ incomes, there is a need to strengthen the capacity 
of the respective line agencies to assess investment proposals, monitor and enforce approved 
investments’  compliance  with  law  and  their  contractual  and  license  conditions,  and  not 
compromise the integrity of natural resources. This can be accomplished through appropriate 
land suitability assessment, classification, zoning, and ground demarcation of various categories 
of forests and agricultural land. This is best facilitated by building capacities of the institutions 
concerned at the provincial level, supported by enhanced capacity at the national level, in 
screening and appraisal techniques that include economic feasibility, social acceptability, and 
environmental stability as formal approval requirements. Supporting associated investments in 
land-based public projects, upon which such processes can be applied, constructs a framework 
of “learning by doing”. It also ensures a direct impact on sector productivity as subproject 
investments will address a range of sector objectives (including agriculture commercialization, 
natural resource protection, and food security). 
 
14.  The Project is consistent with ADB’s long-term strategic framework 2008–2020 (Strategy 
2020) for Lao PDR in promoting environmentally sustainable growth based on natural resources 
protection.14 Economic  growth  will  be  inclusive,  as  resource  protection  disproportionately 
benefits  the  poorest,  and  subproject  investment  selection  criteria  will  ensure  targeting  of 
benefits. ADB’s strategy focuses on two key drivers of change: (i) good governance, and (ii) 
capacity development and formation of partnerships (e.g., with IFAD). Rural infrastructure also 
figures significantly in project design, in accordance with one of ADB’s core specializations. In 
addition,  the  Project  exploits  regional  integration  possibilities,  e.g.,  by  linking  with  Greater 
Mekong Subregion (GMS) based initiatives, including the East–West Economic Corridor.

2.  Investment in Resource Management and Productivity Enhancement 
22.  The capacity building activities in component 1 will have equipped decision-making 
agencies  with  the  skills  to  identify,  prioritize,  and  appraise  investments.  Applying  the 
strengthened capacities, an associated program of subproject investments will be implemented. 
These investments (beginning in year 2 of the Project, and once capacity building has begun) 
will contribute to meeting the Government’s overall objectives of the ANR sector—food security 
and poverty reduction; sector transition (intensification, diversification, value addition) and rural 
commercialization; and sustainability of natural resource utilization.17 
 
23.  Small- and medium-sized subprojects identified for project financing will replicate or 
expand  previously  implemented  development  initiatives  in  similar  agro-ecological  zones  to 
extend  or  widen  the  benefit  to  local  communities.  The  process  will  comprise  district 
identification, provincial technical ratification and prioritization, and national review and approval, 
followed by provincial implementation and management. Evaluation of these publicly funded 
investments  will  require  an  appraisal  process  that  facilitates  incorporation  of  social  and 
environmental safeguards, in addition to technical and economic feasibility analyses. While food 
security and poverty reduction will be the focus in the upland areas, to enhance overall food 
security, the strategy in the lowlands will be to promote integration with regional markets and 
enhance smallholder participation in them.  
 
24.  Subproject design will be carried out incorporating social and environmental safeguards 
and other social and gender development considerations. Subprojects will be formulated at the 
district level, using demand-based procedures including a comprehensive needs assessment 
with guidance from the provinces, specified by the Project. The target group for subproject

3.  Project Management 
26.  The Project has a strong capacity building focus, which must be effectively managed at 
the national level to ensure consistency of application. Similarly, the implementation of 6–13 
subprojects  in  each  province,  all  identified  using  bottom-up  procedures  with  possible 
multiagency  implementation,  will  demand  a  high  level  of  project  management  skills.  The 
component will provide technical support for this process while providing resources to establish 
and operate a management structure at both national and provincial levels. At national level, the 
component will establish a small project coordination office (PCO) within MAF’s DOP, providing 
resources to operate the facility with vehicles, equipment, and an operating budget as well as 
international and national training expertise. Provincial project offices (PPOs) will be provided 
office equipment and vehicles, together with operating budgets and incremental national staff, to 
support project management and selection and screening of subprojects. 
 
C.  Special Features 
27.  One significant special feature of the Project is support to devolution of responsibility for 
management of the country’s natural resources to provincial and district levels. With devolution 
of land management to lower echelons of government, there is a need to enable local levels to 
make decisions regarding land allocation. The incorporation of safeguard considerations in this 
decision-making process is critical to the protection of livelihood sources for rural communities 
and maintaining the environmental integrity of the area.

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Institutional Impact 
50.  The overall value of capacity building activities to the economy was not quantified, but 
improved national and provincial capabilities to make informed decisions about investment in 
the sector (public, private, and from FDI) will contribute significantly to the Government being 
able to take control of the land allocation process on a more rigorous basis. This will enable it to 
protect the interests of smallholders whose livelihoods depend on the natural resources under 
their area of control. The increase in technical capacity will lead to considerable efficiencies 
within the future land allocation process by clearly identifying areas suitable for different forms of 
agricultural and forestry production, and demarcating areas set aside for protection—while 
maximizing economic rents for the state from land concessions. 
 
B.  Social Impact 
51.  An analysis of the project benefits indicates that the more significant social impacts 
caused by the subprojects will be improved livelihoods and reduced levels of poverty for the 
population of the project area. Land suitability assessments and land use planning will enhance 
farmers’ awareness of suitability for various crops to maximize benefits, and facilitate land 
allocation and titling—providing security of tenure and associated benefits. The provision of 
improved  road  access  to  ethnic  minorities  and  farmers  living  in  isolated  and  inaccessible 
mountain areas is likely to have a positive impact, providing them with an outlet for their produce 
and access to lower priced household commodities, agricultural inputs, as well as health and 
education facilities. The Project is classified category A for indigenous peoples, and an ethnic 
group development framework agreed in accordance with the Government’s applicable laws 
and regulations and ADB’s Policy on Indigenous Peoples (1998). The framework will help 
extend subproject positive impacts to ethnic groups and mitigate negative impacts, if any. A 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 10. A summary ethnic group

17
development framework is in Appendix 11 and a detailed ethnic group development framework 
is in Supplementary Appendix H. 
 
52.  Improvement of rural access roads, irrigation facilities, and other rural infrastructure will 
be within existing road alignments as much as possible. It is envisaged that irrigation facilities 
and other items of infrastructure will be rehabilitated in their current locations. Priority will be 
given to those subprojects that can avoid or minimize resettlement impacts. If any exist, they are 
expected  to  be  insignificant  (category  B).  A  resettlement  framework  has  been  prepared 
(Appendix 12 and Supplementary Appendix I) and sets out the resettlement policy, screening, 
and planning procedures that the Project will follow when preparing a resettlement plan if 
required. 
 
53.  Gender impacts will be facilitated through consultation with local women in the design of 
subprojects and by their inclusion in project activities (including extension services and training). 
Infrastructure management bodies will include women. Gender training will be provided and 
linked to this concrete action in subproject preparation. Gender focal points may be established 
in villages to promote improved agricultural practices, taking account of women’s traditional 
rights in land reallocation and land titling (Appendix 13 and Supplementary Appendix J). More 
generally,  improved  road  access  will  open  up  new  opportunities  for  women  who  lived  in 
previously isolated, rural communities—giving better access to education and health services, 
as  well  as  facilitating  employment  and  investment  opportunities  (Appendix  13  and 
Supplementary Appendix J). 
 
C.  Environmental Impact 
54.  The Project’s primary focus is on capacity building for sustainable ANR management, 
which  entails  nonintrusive  initiatives  with  institutions.  The  developed  capacity  will  enhance 
environmental benefits and promote the environmental stability of subprojects. In examining 
land concessions, MAF and PAFOs will ensure that encroachment does not occur into protected 
areas and that any commercial ventures already allocated concessions in such areas will have 
their lease revised accordingly. Protection forest will also be clearly demarcated on land use 
and suitability maps to be prepared under the proposed Project. Based on the likely investments 
envisaged, the Project has been classified environmental category B. An initial environmental 
examination  (IEE)  for  the  Project  and  the  two  sample  subprojects  was  undertaken 
(Supplementary Appendix K) in accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002). The IEEs 
show that most of the potential impacts will be positive, that no significant adverse impacts are 
anticipated, and an environmental impact assessment is not required. However, to ensure that 
all potentially adverse impacts are mitigated, careful screening of subprojects will be carried out 
and  an  environmental  management  plan  specifying  mitigation  measures  and  funding 
requirements will be a prerequisite for approval. In addition, an environmental assessment and 
review  framework  has  been  prepared  (Supplementary  Appendix  K)  to  guide  the  EA  in 
undertaking environmental assessments of subprojects to be selected during implementation. 
 
D.  Economic Impact 
55.  Benefits from rural road rehabilitation include reduced travel costs and times. Indirect 
benefits include the diversification of sources of income, higher levels of agricultural productivity, 
greater  diversification  of  market-oriented  agriculture  crops,  improved  access  to  health  and 
education services, and reduced costs of inputs and household commodities—all leading to 
reduced  levels  of  poverty  among  communities  served  by  the  roads.  This  is  confirmed  by 
economic  internal  rate  of  return  estimates  of  23.5%  for  a  sample  rural  road  rehabilitation 
subproject,  based  on  quantifiable  benefits.  The  benefit  of  irrigation  rehabilitation  includes 
increased  agriculture  production  and  diversification  to  higher  value  crops.  The  sample

18    
subproject analyzed shows the intensification from a single rain-fed rice crop to two irrigated rice 
crops, although other higher valued options are available with the more secure dry season 
water  supplies  leading  to  an  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of  19.3%.  All  the  benefits 
anticipated are incremental in relation to the without-project scenario, where it may be expected 
that  the  incidence  of  land-use  conflicts  increase,  social  and  environmental  consequences 
intensify, and suboptimal economic returns (to the state and public lands and to Lao labor) 
worsen. Detailed economic analysis is in Appendix 14. 
 
E.  Assumptions and Risks 
56.  The design logic of the Project assumes that inflows of FDI into the Lao PDR continue, 
there is ongoing availability of appropriate improved agriculture technology upon which to base 
productivity improvements, processes of increasing regional integration and market participation 
underpin improving producer incentives, and the broad mix of government policies in the ANR 
sector remain consistent. 
 
57.  The  main  institutional  risk  to  the  Project  lies  in  potential  conflict  between  certain 
provinces which have recently enjoyed considerable latitude in the award of land concessions 
and state agencies (such as NLMA) which are trying to standardize and rationalize the situation 
from  a  national  perspective.  This  risk  has  been  mitigated  by  involving  high-level  political 
authority from the provinces in the design process. A second risk concerns the allocation of 
funds for O&M of rural infrastructure rehabilitated under the Project. This is a systemic and 
ongoing issue, as cash-limited provincial authorities are responsible for maintenance of state 
assets but receive few resources from the national budget to carry out routine and periodic 
maintenance. This will be mitigated by requiring provinces in which subprojects are located to 
sign formal commitments to provide financing to meet O&M expenses, and by the Government 
providing a specific assurance that it will allocate sufficient funds for the same purpose. 
 
58.  A third risk is that capacity building initiatives are insufficient to achieve the competence 
needed for improved natural resource management, particularly in land suitability identification. 
This is mitigated by the continual input of technical specialists in the provinces throughout the 
first 3 years of implementation to provide the necessary support. The governance issue raised 
above will determine if the technical recommendations are seriously considered in making land 
allocation decisions. 
 
59.  A final risk is that trained staff will leave their posts after receiving training under the 
Project.  This  remains  a  constant  threat  in  economies  where  skilled  individuals  are  few  in 
number and opportunities for advancement are plenty. The broader project benefit can be 
served as long as the trained individual continues to serve economic development within the 
Lao PDR and performance-based incentives are instituted.

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Background 
1.  The economy of the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) is largely dependent 
on an undeveloped and low-productivity agriculture and natural resources (ANR) sector to 
support the majority of its population. The proportion of households that can be described as 
agricultural remains high (at around 80%) and over 90% of these produce rice, mainly for their 
own consumption. Sector growth rates averaged almost 5% in the 5 years to 2000, but have 
declined since to about 2%–3% per year. This growth came mainly from yield increases in rice, 
but also from modest moves toward higher value cropping in lowland areas. Agriculture has 
remained a relatively extensive activity compared with other countries in the region, but national 
rice yields are still low by regional standards. Input use is still about one-tenth that of most 
countries in the region. National agricultural value added remains low, as is the openness of the 
sector (the lowest in the Greater Mekong Subregion). 
 
2.  The Lao PDR achieved national food self-sufficiency at the turn of the century. It is 
widely agreed that aggregate annual production of rice, other grains and staples (roots, tubers, 
etc.) on average meet national calorific requirements. However, the entire population does not 
enjoy secure food supplies. Seasonal and local deficits, especially in upland and remote areas, 
still occur with some frequency. 
 
3.  As well as geographic (mountainous topography) conditions and particular subsector 
issues (such as the irrigated area as a proportion of total cropped area being low), the rural 
economy remains broadly affected by specific deficiencies including (i) the availability of rural 
finance, (ii) a generally underdeveloped private sector, and (iii) the poor state of the transport 
network (especially roads—both rural roads and links connecting the Lao PDR to other Greater 
Mekong Subregion countries). Geographical isolation is a major cause of poverty, as much of 
the rural population has limited access to markets, employment opportunities, or social services. 
 
4.  Overall, the economy is primarily agrarian and natural resource-based, despite abundant 
natural resources and an apparently favorable policy climate that has facilitated economic 
growth at the national level. ANR sector transition (i.e., agricultural intensification, diversification, 
and agro-industrialization) has not yet occurred, and the sector’s contribution to national poverty 
reduction has so far been modest. 
 
5.  In response to the Sixth National Socio Economic Development Plan (2006–2010) and 
National Growth and Poverty Eradication Strategy objectives, the Ministry of Agriculture and 
Forestry (MAF) has formulated four goals and 13 measures for the sector to guide development. 
However,  the  current  planning  system  does  not  embody  economic  prioritization  or  choice 
between alternatives (i.e., more robust policy making is required, especially at local levels). In 
addition, whatever objectives may exist in state plans, inadequate operational resources and 
significant  control  over  expenditures  by  provincial  authorities  (because  of  their  tax-raising 
powers) can frustrate and/or undermine state objectives. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
and the World Bank are working to put in place a medium-term expenditure framework at 
sectoral  and  national  levels.  It  is  questionable  whether  the  structure  of  MAF  operations 
(historically developed as an input and service provider across a range of activities) can meet 
the  needs of  increasingly  export-oriented,  sophisticated, and  service-demanding  production 
systems. 
 
6.  Although problems in governance conditions have been identified and described for 
many years, the relatively poor sector governance is now an obvious constraint to the promotion 
of sustainable and equitable resource-based development. Agricultural growth has the potential

to benefit the majority of the poor directly. However, this growth (including in foreign direct 
investment [FDI]) depends on the—currently absent—transparency and predictability in the 
implementation of investment laws, the enforcement of contracts, and management of the trade 
regime and taxation procedures. Similarly, farmers, agribusiness enterprises, and investors 
must have confidence in relation to their land tenure and usufruct rights to ensure security of 
their property and investment. Such rights are largely unenforceable at present. Aggregate 
agricultural growth also depends on protecting national water, soil, and forest resources, e.g., by 
controlling the commercial and population-driven loss of forest, by managing the award of large-
scale land concession, and other significant resource alienation. However, government capacity 
to monitor and regulate and to impose penalties for illegal acts is extremely modest. Changes 
required to increase the long-term sustainable sector growth rate will depend largely on the 
overall governance function, and how well domestic organizations and institutions perform. 
 
B.  Recent Developments and Current Issues 
7.  The most notable feature of the ANR sector is the unprecedented pace at which the 
sector  (and  thereby  the  country  itself)  is  being  integrated  with  neighboring  economies, 
particularly through flows of FDI. This inward investment is manifest in (i) cross-border contract 
farming arrangements (typically between Lao smallholders and Thai, Chinese, or Vietnamese 
purchasers,  traders  and  processors);  and  (ii)  plantation-style  commodity  production 
concessions. Many of these involve Chinese (for rubber, mainly in the north), Vietnamese 
(mainly rubber and coffee in the south), Korean (Jotropha for bio-diesel fuel), and Indian (pulp 
and paper based on fast-growing wood fiber) companies. Many of the Chinese and Vietnamese 
agencies  are  State  Owned  Enterprises,  often  exploiting  historical  political  and  patronage 
linkages with particular provinces. The scale of these developments is significant (153,000 
hectares have been allocated in Savannakhet alone and total national land concessions may 
number  900  separate  agreements).  Concession  areas  in  the  southern  provinces  already 
represent 35% of the paddy area (Table A3).

8.  Such concession investments have the potential to create large numbers of jobs for the 
local population; and can bring skills, technology, intellectual property, etc. to the Lao PDR. 
However, major concerns remain. Land is given to applicants for long lease periods. This is 
often done under provincial authority, the status of which is unclear, and whose administrative 
and  financial  processes  are  opaque.  Lease  periods  of  20,  30,  or  50  years  are  common. 
Concessions  are  frequently  given  on  a  first-come,  first-served  basis  without  any  proper 
feasibility or safeguards-based analysis. There is little consideration as to the economic impact

9.  The Government’s response to such arrangements is ambiguous. It involves confusion 
vis-à-vis legislation, and the mandates and authority of institutions; and outright conflict between 
the  state  and  certain  provinces.  The  public  sector  response  can  best  be  described  as 
administratively  and  technically  underdeveloped—it  simply  does  not  have  the  capacity  to 
appraise and monitor such arrangements. The limited capacity of ANR institutions in this regard 
is the core sector problem and desired outcome to remedy this situation. Without the Project, 
the nature of many such investments could be (i) environmentally damaging, either through 
relatively short-term exploitation or longer-term neglect; (ii) non-transparent, thus benefiting 
foreign and nonpoor interests; and (iii) economically suboptimal, in terms of adding to domestic 
employment, income-generation, and wealth-creation. 
 
10.  There are also concerns from the impact of major international price changes (rice - 
doubling between early 2007 and early 2008) and to fuel-based inputs (inorganic fertilizers, 
pesticides, herbicides, etc.). These changes have affected the dynamics of rice production and 
consumption in ways that remain unclear, as the rice economy is characterized by a complex 
interplay of production and consumption factors. At the policy level, a proper understanding is 
required of (i) the extent to which rice production should be promoted (in aggregate and at 
specific locations), and (ii) the opportunity costs of any particular level of national food security. 
Perhaps even more urgently, at the investment level, specific interventions are needed to 
increase the productivity of rice and other staples. This may be achieved through replication of 
successful irrigation rehabilitation schemes; and promotion and formation of farmer groups (to 
improve post-harvest handling, undertake marketing, devolve scheme management, etc.). 
 
11.  Recent FDI and land-based investments from neighboring countries in the ANR sector 
may be seen as a gold rush. However, as the economy becomes more formally integrated into 
worldwide relationships in the longer term, it will be more affected by global (as opposed to 
merely local and regional) factors. These will include the effects of engaging new and higher 
value  products,  intensifying  and  extending  supply  chains,  more  rigorous  quality  standards, 
better information, etc. There is an urgent need to strengthen Lao PDR value chains, add value 
to  existing  products,  and  encourage  product  diversification  through  specific  investments  to 
address and exploit such possibilities. At a policy level, another need is to improve the Lao 
PDR’s ability to engage in global (World Trade Organization) and regional (e.g., Association of 
Southeast Asian Nations [ASEAN], ASEAN Free Trade Area, and ANR trade based on proper 
sanitary and phyto-sanitary measures. 
 
12.  Overall, securing the natural resource base is a necessary but insufficient condition for 
ANR  sector  development.  Complementary  investments  must  raise  sector  productivity  on  a 
sustainable and equitable basis. 
 
13.  The project design is based on identified sector problems. It has incorporated lessons 
from previous interventions by taking a strategic approach, focusing on binding constraints, and 
maximizing  donor  coordination.  It  integrates  with  other  ADB  interventions,  e.g.,  in  public 
expenditure management and national and sector trade facilitation. A sector lending modality is 
required because it is necessary to (i) address sector capacity needs centered on the land 
issues; and (ii) promote increased ANR productivity and natural resource management at a 
range of specific locations, with a variety of sector objectives (poverty reduction, food security, 
trade promotion, etc.). The subproject identification and selection processes will ensure that 
inclusive economic growth is fostered.

D.  Prioritization Mechanism 
12.  Apart from the criteria used in the screening process, additional criteria will be used to 
facilitate the prioritization of subprojects given their different objectives and outcomes. A score- 
based system will be adopted for the three categories of subprojects: (i) rural poverty-focused 
subprojects,  (ii)  rural  commercialization-based  subprojects,  and  (iii)  natural  resource 
management-based  projects.  Different  weightings  will  be  applied  to  the  different  types  of 
subprojects to facilitate this prioritization process.  
 
1.  Rural Poverty Reduction Subprojects 
13.  For rural poverty reduction subprojects, the indicators shall have the following weights: 
(i) A = the EIRR (10%); (ii) B = the number of individuals below the established poverty line 
assisted per $1,000 invested (40%); (iii) C = the equity contribution of beneficiaries (10%); and 
(iv) D = the district is considered poor (40%). The first criterion is an indication of economic 
viability, the second an indicator of project impact and efficiency of impact (particularly on 
poverty  reduction),  the  third  is  an  indicator  of  ownership  by  subproject  proponents  or 
beneficiaries, and the fourth is to ensure prioritization of proposals from priority poor/upland 
districts.  
 
14.  The highest data for each of the evaluation criteria from the subprojects being evaluated 
will be given a rating of 1.00 point. The scores for evaluation criteria of the other proposals will 
be computed accordingly as a ratio to the highest score. Proposals will be ranked according to 
their combined scores using the formula below: 
 
I = (0.10×A) + (0.40×B) + (0.10×C) + (0.40×D) 
 
2.  Rural Commercialization Subprojects 
15.  For rural commercialization subprojects, the criteria indicators shall have the following 
weights: (i) A = the EIRR (60%); (ii) B = the number of individuals below the established poverty 
line assisted per $1,000 invested, excluding labor in kind (15%); (iii) C = the equity contribution 
of beneficiaries (25%). Proposals will be ranked according to their combined scores using the 
following formula: 
 
I = (0.60×A) + (0.15×B) + (0.25×C)

3.  Natural Resources Management Subprojects 
16.  For natural resources management subprojects, an additional indicator is needed to 
quantify the degree of threat to the resource. This will be calculated on a score of 1–5, with 
1 being a low level of threat, and 5 being an extreme and immediate threat to the resource. The 
degree of threat will be confirmed by an environmental specialist during the feasibility study, and 
confirmed at later stages of assessment. An extreme and immediate threat would mean that the 
proposal  is  more  deserving  of  an  investment  to  mitigate  the  threat.  For  natural  resource

EIRR (25%); (ii) B = the number of individuals below the established poverty line assisted per

degree of threat (25%). Proposals will be ranked according to their combined scores using the 
following formula: 
 
I = (0.25×A) + (0.25×B) + (0.25×C) + (0.25×D)

17.  The allocation of grant funds between provinces for the implementation of subprojects is 
proposed to be made through an initial equal allocation of $2 million to each of the provinces,

opportunity  to  receive an  allocation  based  on  the  incidence  of  poverty.  This  constitutes  a

provinces with their diverse capital base. Allocation of grant funds among potential subprojects

A. Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The  Sixth  National  Socio  Economic  Development  Plan  (2006–2010)  proposes  prioritized  investment  in  the

comprises four goals and 13 measures to achieve these goals. The four goals are (i) increased food production and 
security; (ii) increased production of materials for agro-processing; (iii) stabilization of shifting cultivation (the main 
strategy  of  poverty  reduction  in  the  47  poorest  districts  while  providing  for  environmental  protection);  and 
(iv) sustainable  forest  management.  As  the  Project  will  develop  sector  management  capacities  and  finance 
subprojects, contributing to investment in resource management and productivity enhancement management, the 
design is supportive of sector objectives. 
 
The country strategy and program 2007–2011 of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) aims to promote pro-poor, 
sustainable growth led by the private sector, by improving policies and institutional capacity to support broad-based, 
private sector-led growth.b It proposes to support the building of a legal and regulatory framework and developing 
capacity in sectors and subsectors—specifically identifying agriculture as a target. The strategy supports greater 
involvement of civil society and mass organizations in the delivery of agriculture and basic social services. Support 
will be provided to private business associations to improve their ability to network, develop business skills, and 
advocate on behalf of their membership—expanding livelihood opportunities for rural women as well as men in 
commercial agriculture and small and medium-sized enterprise development. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis  Targeting Classification:     General intervention 
1. Key Issues 
A key poverty issue is the impact from foreign direct investment (FDI) that limits smallholder access to land and forest 
resources from which smallholders obtain their traditional subsistence existence. There is poor coordination between 
central and provincial/district levels in the application of policies for FDI. The Government has the right to determine 
and change land categories, allowing local authorities to reclassify village land from “productive” to “unproductive” to 
meet concessionaires’ demands. Procedures for awarding concessions are not clear and awards take place in an ad 
hoc fashion. This institutional weakness and poor governance is compounded by a lack of awareness of safeguard 
issues. The demand for land by plantation-style FDI has been directed at areas previously used in swidden 
production systems, where ethnic groups predominate and poverty is most apparent. Some 75% of poor households 
countrywide are made up of members of ethnic groups living in remote and upland areas on marginally productive 
land. 
 
2.  Design Features 
To address these issues, the Project will develop the capacities of the provincial agriculture and forestry offices to 
identify land suitability for a range of potential crops so that informed decisions can be made when allocating land. 
The  capacity  building  will  extend  to  strengthening  agency  staff’s  understanding  of  environmental  and  social 
safeguards to protect the interests of traditional users of the resources under consideration. The Project will also 
provide funding for demand-based rural infrastructure and other successful subprojects to increase agricultural 
productivity to facilitate smallholder participation in commercialization in the market economy. While many of the 
subprojects are expected to be small-scale rural infrastructure investments, subproject design will incorporate land 
tenure activities to protect the interests of traditional land-users in subproject areas. The skills developed in land 
suitability mapping using geographic information systems can readily be applied to subproject design to demark 
protected and production forest areas to be managed by villagers. These subprojects will be selected through a 
screening process, using established criteria and safeguards outlined in Supplementary Appendix C, which ensure 
identification of appropriate beneficiaries with attention to gender issues and indigenous people’s concerns. The 
Project will train implementing staff in developing and applying mechanisms for the participation of all vulnerable 
groups, women, and ethnic minorities; and ensuring community demand is articulated.

II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
 
A.  Findings of Social Analysis 
In the year 2000–01, 304,100 households were classified “poor” throughout the country. This decreased to 166,600 
by 2005. The population of the five target provinces is 1.8 million, ranging from 0.8 million in Savannakhet to 
0.11 million in Sekong. While the poor represent 38% of the project area’s population, the incidence of poverty in 
participating provinces varies from 42% in Savannakhet to only 5% in Sekong and 7% in Attapeu. The provinces with 
the greatest number and highest percentage of poor are Savannakhet and Champassak. At the village and district 
level, other factors are brought into consideration in assessing poverty, including access to education, health 
services, road access, as well as access to clean drinking water. These criteria significantly alter the perspective of 
poverty from the income-based assessment with individual households. 
 
There are 40 districts in the five provinces, of which 19 are considered priority poor (7 in Savannakhet, 4 in 
Champassak, 3 in Salavan and Attapeu each, and 2 in Sekong). Within these poor districts, household poverty levels 
average over 50% although Champassak has a figure closer to 20%. Assessed on a village basis, about 70% of the 
villages are poor; this ranges from 50% in Champassak to over 80% in Attapeu and Sekong. Proportional figures are 
misleading, though, and the actual numbers of poor households are by far the greatest in Savannakhet and 
Champassak, accounting for over 70% of the poor households in the participating provinces. A further dimension of 
poverty relates to the predominance of ethnic groups within the target area. About half of the population in the 
five provinces is comprised of indigenous peoples known in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) as 
ethnic groups, mostly from the Mon-Khmer language family. The proportion of ethnic groups is highest in Sekong 
(88%) and Attapeu (63%) but actual numbers are greatest in Savannakhet and Champassak. Poverty is significantly 
higher among minority groups than in lowland Lao communities. 
 
Because of this isolation, villagers are heavily dependent on forest access for daily edibles and non-timber forest 
products, some of which are sold to earn cash for food purchase. In the five provinces, there are serious economic 
consequences for poor villagers that lose access to forest resources through unrestrained concession award and 
unplanned relocation. Some concessionaires are clearing and converting forestland contrary to government policy. 
FDI has increased the risk of staple food shortages. Ethnic minority villages are required to cease shifting cultivation 
and resettle at lower elevations, forming larger communities where government services can be provided.c  
 
Another difficulty with merged administrations from resettlement is that several different ethnic groups are often 
grouped together in one village or location, requiring longer preparation time for consultation with each set of elders. 
Those villages that have been resettled within walking distance of their old land continue to grow upland rice in these 
locations. However, because of the distance to these fields, they are not able to clear, plant, and maintain as large an 
area as before. In addition, some villagers complain of declining production caused by a combination of increased 
population (as a result of merging of villages) and land degradation. Government policy on reducing shifting 
cultivation may also have limited village access to sufficient productive land.

C. Gender and Development 
 
1. Key Issues 
Rural Lao women are primarily responsible for maintaining family food security, a role often underestimated. 
Prevailing cultural values tend to disadvantage women in terms of their participation in politics and decision-making 
processes, and they are underrepresented in village committees. Similarly, ethnic group women are not well 
presented in government, particularly extension workers, health care workers, and teachers. By virtue of their 
geographic location, they are isolated from resources and services. They are also the least able to participate in 
decision making, partly because of illiteracy and cultural traditions. Linguistic barriers and cultural attitudes toward 
education perpetuate low human development and the vicious cycle of poverty in which many ethnic groups find 
themselves. 
 
The Government has asked all ministries to develop strategies and action plans to promote gender equality at 
national, provincial, district, and village levels. Line agencies have begun to mainstream gender concerns. However, 
MAF has not started integrating gender into its planning cycle; its main efforts are in donor-funded projects. MAF has 
a gender focal point and women advancement committee but its role and responsibilities are not clear—nor is it 
strong enough to integrate gender policies into practice. Constraints on gender mainstreaming in MAF are a poor 
understanding of gender concept and strategies, lack of resource persons with gender professional knowledge, and 
no statistical information related to gender issues. 
 
Land rights of women show a difference in the names and or titles that appear on the land documents and the origin 
of the land. Only 16% of land was registered in the wife’s name, although 40% of the land came from the wife’s 
parents. Fifty-eight percent of land was registered in the husband’s name, although only 18% of the land came from 
the husband’s parents. Part of this situation can be attributed to the lack of knowledge on and difficulty in accessing 
information on women’s land rights. In addition, except for selected Mon-Khmer groups such as Brao, it is a generally 
held view that men are the head of household, so their names appear on administrative documents.

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  In view of the sector lending modality, an economic analysis has been carried out on the 
proposed loan based on Asian Development Bank (ADB) guidelines contained in Economics 
Research Division Technical Note No. 14: Economic Analysis of a Sector Loan.1 The proposed 
Project is an investment grant. However, because of the significant number and location of 
potential subprojects within the target provinces, it was not possible to identify all subprojects 
during design—nor was it appropriate, as the Government has already demonstrated capacity 
to implement a sector modality project. The Project also seeks to influence policy development 
and thereby qualifies as a sector loan. More detailed analysis of two representative subprojects 
(to  confirm  they  are  economically  viable  and  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction)  is  in 
Supplementary Appendix L. Further material on the sector (including its planning context) is in 
Appendix 3. 
 
B.  Rationale for Government and ADB Involvement 
2.  The  Government  is  ultimately  responsible  for  management  of  the  country’s  natural 
resources  to  ensure  their  current  and  continuing  productivity.  With  the  recent  and  largely 
unmanaged surge in foreign direct investment (FDI), negative impacts are already becoming 
obvious.  The  incidence  of  conflict  over  land  has  increased  dramatically,  with  both 
concessionaires and traditional landowners uncertain of their rights. FDI has effectively denied 
access by traditional users of forest areas, and their livelihoods have been threatened. The 
short-term response was to introduce a moratorium on the issue of new land concessions until 
May 2008. A longer-term solution is needed to rationalize this potentially valuable source of 
investment, and manage it to minimize negative externalities. 
 
3.  Another part of the rationale for government involvement is that rural infrastructure is 
largely a public good (benefits are largely non-excludable and non-subtractable).2 Infrastructure 
investments tend to require large capital resources, which preclude private investment, since 
the means for recovering rents or user charges are not well developed in the Lao People’s 
Democratic  Republic  (Lao  PDR),  in  spite  of  some  unachieved  policies  regarding  irrigation 
management and transfer.3 With the exception of irrigation facilities and water supplies, where 
target beneficiaries can be clearly identified, benefits from investment are distributed over a 
large and unidentifiable number of users. This reinforces the public nature of the investment. 
Similarly, the proposed support to producer associations and farmer groups is not likely to be 
carried out by the private sector. 
 
4.   ADB’s comparative advantage as a participant in the Project arises from three main 
sources.  Firstly,  previous  long-term  agriculture  and  natural  resources  and  multi-sector 
experience (both policy and project-based) is unmatched by any other donor in the Lao PDR. 
This has contributed to robust project design and will continue to underlie and inform project 
implementation, especially as a mixture of policy and technical support is envisaged. A history 
of long-term cooperation with the Ministry of Agriculture and Forestry (MAF) (particularly the 
Department of Planning) will provide a solid foundation for long-term implementation.

15.  The major  economic risk to the successful outcome of the Project is the need for

J.  Conditions Attached to the Loan 
19.  Most  conditions  for  the  Project  relate  to  subproject  identification  and  have  been 
incorporated in the selection criteria. The Project is intended to have national impact through 
policy development in respect of land tenure, issuance of land concessions, incorporation of 
safeguards, and more rigor in investment appraisal. It will also influence the protection of user 
rights on traditional upland farming areas. In addition, it will develop awareness of the need for 
safeguards  (through  the  associated  capacity  development  technical  assistance)  when 
considering proposed investments. The criteria for subprojects will ensure that these aspects 
are considered in the selection process (Appendix 5 and Supplementary Appendix C) and are 
confirmed in the loan conditions. 
 
K.  Economic Analysis of Representative Subprojects 
20.  Two representative subprojects were analyzed to determine their suitability for funding. 
Each subproject demonstrated EIRRs in excess of 12%, ranging from 19.3% to 23.5% based on 
the identified net benefit flows. In each case, additional benefits from the investment could not 
be readily quantified and estimates were considered conservative. Sensitivity tests were carried 
out  to  the  main  potential  variables  that  might  affect  the  findings,  including  price  declines, 
increases in capital costs, and a reduction in utilization. Sensitivity to routine and periodic 
maintenance was also analyzed, with utilization declining to pre-rehabilitation levels after the 
maintenance ceased. In most cases, the benefits were not sensitive to changes in price levels 
or to increases in unit investment costs. The area of greatest sensitivity was identified from 
maintenance practices. Where the maintenance ceased after 5 years of operation, the EIRRs 
fell dramatically below the cost of capital. In cases where the maintenance ceased 10 years 
after completion, the EIRRs were significantly reduced but not below zero, as most of the 
benefits would have been received before deterioration of the infrastructure. The economic 
benefit from subproject investments will, because of the selection criteria used, be higher than 
the opportunity cost of capital and constitute sound economic investments without negative 
social and environmental impacts.
